page.title: 07TOURISM DARTMOOR
page.content: Elliot's Hill School of Riding is based in the farm which is a medieval and Victorian building. The owners have farmed here since 1949. They opened the stables in 1980. The school operates from April to October and it is run by the farmer, his wife and three employees. They teach ten pupils at a time to ride. If they take clients out for a days trekking they may travel 25 miles. On an hours ride they may travel 3 miles on the 110 acre farm. The ponies are fed on oats in the summer and hay in the winter. Hay is grown on the farm and the oats are bought in Ashburton. It costs about Â£15 a week to feed one pony and there are about 12 of them. The riding helps to pay for their upkeep. Lessons cost Â£3.50 per hour, Â£6.50 half a day and Â£13 for a full day.
